column8: Is the original article open access?
column11: Does the PPPR include a conflict of interest statement?
column12: Do PPPR authors state that there may be a conflict of interest?
column21: issues_detail
column22: How many words are included in the PPPR (in main text, excluding references, etc)?
column23: Does the PPPR include analysis of original article data?
column24: Does the PPPR include analysis of new data?
column27: Do original authors assert their core claims remain unchanged?
column28: Did reply involve collection of new data?

column21: Asserts that there are "inaccuracies and misrepresentations" in original. Argues that several claims are "materially incorrect" or "false" . Argues that original did not use relevant data in their analysis - "did not review program data submitted to the NQF for the 2017 reendorsement cycle"
Asserts that data is missing from figure 2 and figure was not properly referenced in the text

Asserts that the observed effect is "highly susceptible to residual confounding" which the analysis did not adequately address. Also criticises not transforming BMI data and categorising a continuous variable.
Suggests there is a deeper problem (internal market) beyond the original authors focus (NHS privatisation)
Suggests claims are not appropriately caveated; offers a different interpretation
Suggests a different research question is more relevant. Suggests design was suboptimal for the research question.
Challenges the methods and operational definitions used to identify certain cell types.
Suggests that linear regression coefficient should be adjusted
Raises a potential alternative explanation or point of query
Identifies what appears to be a duplicated row in a table
Suggests using subgroups in the analysis, suggests some relevant data was missed, runs a new analysis based on the additional data which changes the results, suggests a more cautious interpretation
Argues that the measurement tool "is not validated, potentially highly biased". Criticizes the lack of a placebo control. Identifies a potential typographical error.
Argues for a different analysis strategy
Suggests wording of conclusions is misleading
Suggests that the post-hoc Bayesian analyses is an example of confirmation bias and is not "impartial". Criticises the subjectivity of the analyses and use of a 'severely skeptical' prior
Argues that the analyses should have accounted for early trial stopping
Critcises the measurement instrument and authors interpretation
Suggests lack of effect may be due to under-treatment, emphasises role of a potential confound

Suggests inclusion criteria are not clearly reported, suggest potential confound of other treatments is not reported/considered, suggests potential undertreatment; disagrees with generalisability of results
Questions generalisability of the results, suggests pain mediciation as potential confound, criticizes exclusion criteria
Suggests prevalence estimates are biased by inclusion criteria and statistical adjustments
Suggests original interpretation/analysis failed to account for important confounds

Identifies potential confounds, suggests use of different methods (full sequencing), questions original authors interpretation, identifies potential lack of generalisability due to recruitment strategy
Suggests an alternative interpretation
Suggests greater caution needed due to missing data, identifies potential confounds
Suggests additional evidence to include in review
Suggests an important potential confound that was not measured
Suggests the analysis should have been weighted by age
Disagrees with authors interpretation, identifies potential confounders
Suggests different weighting and modeling strategy
Questions several aspects of the original analysis strategy and disagrees with the original interpretation
Suggests alternative interpretation, questions aspects of the analysis (modellign assumptions, equations)
Seems to imply the study was unethical, describing it as "horrible and unnecessary"
suggests guidance level should be reassessed based on a lack of cited RCTs
suggests additional interpretation
flags possible reporting error in figure
suggests an issue that should be covered in the review
suggests an issue that should be covered in the review
suggests additional analysis
suggests additional reporting, highlights potential inconsistency of results with other studies
suugests a potential alternative interpretation and analysis
asks for clarification of diagnostic criteria
Suggests an alternative interpretation
Requests additional information
Criticises methodological heterogenity and small sample size
Suggests additional outcome variable would have been of interest
Suggests one aspect of the original may not be generalizable based on replication data
Presents survey data about the original article that suggests some potential methodological issues
presents the results of a new study that contradict results from the original article
disagrees with original conclusion, critisizes exclusion criteria
asserts that the analysis contains an error which invalidates the conclusions, suggests a control variable that should have been included, critisizes exclusion criteria
suggests a relevant topic - statins - was ommitted from the review
suggests a relevant topic - statins - was ommitted from the review
disagrees with interpretation (of a part of the review)
suggests an improved methodological approach
criticises methods, disagrees with conclusions, asserts that original analyses do not support conclusions
asks for more information on how subjects were selected, points out potential confounds
challenges original conclusions based on other studies
